titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Meteorological Manuscripts Collection
titlestmt.author: compiled by Staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 09:01

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: An artificial collection of meteorological observations, journals and records kept by Joseph William Bennett (1811-1883), George Dutton (d.1857), Oscar L. Hargar (1843-1887), Benjamin Franklin Harrison, Alfred Shepard Monson (1795-1870), William Charles Redfield (1789-1857), William Maxwell Reed (b.1871), Charles Rich (1809-1862), Minerva Wing, and others, relating to the climate and weather conditions primarily in Connecticut, 1821-1943. Some oversize materials relate to additional states, as well as to European countries.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown, though much of the material in this collection is likely in the public domain. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Some oversize materials are fragile and may require conservation work before use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Meteorological Manuscripts Collection (MS 349). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Elias Loomis, 1883; H. A. Newton, 1870; James H. Craig, 1924; Henry White, 1860, John Reader, 1957, and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An artificial collection of meteorological observations, journals and records kept by Joseph William Bennett (1811-1883), George Dutton (d.1857), Oscar L. Hargar (1843-1887), Benjamin Franklin Harrison, Alfred Shepard Monson (1795-1870), William Charles Redfield (1789-1857), William Maxwell Reed (b.1871), Charles Rich (1809-1862), Minerva Wing, and others, relating to the climate and weather conditions primarily in Connecticut, 1821-1943. Some oversize materials relate to additional states, as well as to European countries.

did.unittitle: "Meteorological Journal kept at New Haven," Conn
Dutton, George (d. 1857): "Registry of Tides and Winds," Fort Taylor, Key West
Harger, Oscar L. (1843-1887): weather recordings in Oxford, Conn., and elsewhere
Monson, Alfred Shepard (1795-1870): "Observations of the Thermometer," New Haven, Conn.
"Meteorological Journal" (or "Register," or "Record"), New York: 15 vols.; last one, for New York and Philadelphia, is by his son John Howard Redfield (1815-1895)
"Meteorological Journal" (or "Register," or "Record"), New York: 15 vols.; last one, for New York and Philadelphia, is by his son John Howard Redfield (1815-1895)
"Meteorological Journal" (or "Register," or "Record"), New York: 15 vols.; last one, for New York and Philadelphia, is by his son John Howard Redfield (1815-1895)
"Meteorological Journal" (or "Register," or "Record"), New York: 15 vols.; last one, for New York and Philadelphia, is by his son John Howard Redfield (1815-1895)
Reed, William Maxwell (1871-): "Will Next Summer be Hotter than Last Summer?": carbon of typescript
Rich, Charles (1809-1862): "Meteorological Journal," New Haven, Conn.; continued by Edward Claudius Herrick (1811-1862)
"Record of Observations on the Weather at Windham, Conn."
Wing, Minerva: meteorological observations, West Charlotte, Vermont

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Oversize items have been boxed up by size; box numbers in listing are not necessarily sequential.
